author: @ajaypatro1554
text: Hy, Nicholas, Myself Ajay I've been meaning to reach out to you for quite some time now, I wanted to know opinion on my roadmap for Data Science for Geospatial Industry, I will not waste your time I will share what I am doing write now and what are my goals are and please give me idea what to do:  I have a postgraduate degree in geoinformatics, but I've had trouble finding a suitable job in the field of spatial analysis. This is mainly because I lacked Python skills. However, as soon as I started the CS50 Python course, I realized there's a whole world of spatial analytics out there (which is essentially like supercharged spatial analysis with data science). I'm currently enrolled in CS50 Python and plan to take CS50 SQL next. After that, I wanted to know if Google's Advanced Data Analytics course is a good choice for someone like me who doesn't have a fundamental understanding of data science and statistics. I'm also interested in statistical learning, but I'm not sure how to go about it since it's currently in R on edX. I did find a book in Python for it, though.  I also have an interest in computer vision applications in the field of earth observation and machine learning for spatial data patterns. Essentially, I want to do what Foursquare and CartoDB are doing in spatial data science, with a focus on image processing for earth observation (although this part can wait for about a year).

text: advice than you may not want to hear: certificates, specializations etc. (academic or corporate) won't help you get a job (unless you know someone who will hire u). Associate/Bachelor/Master/PhD will. When u have that associate/ bachelor/master/PhD, these certificates may help as continuing education.

author: @Recklessness97
text: I took and completed the first data analytics professional certificate course about a month ago now. I found the first course to be quite lack luster. Almost everything taught in it you're able to easily find online and through the internet/youtube videos. Also many of the jobs I applied to could have cared less about the actual certificate I received and more about my portfolio and me actually being able to demonstrate the skills required. I guess what you're paying for is having most of the learning material in one location and prepared for you rather than hoping all over the internet learning from different sources. Mode Analytics is a great website to learn all about analytics and the programing basics you'll need, that's how I learned Python for data analytics along with the free Python "bootcamp" provided by the creators of Python themselves.

author: @rolf7135
text: I started taking it yesterday and have gone throught course 1 and 2. I've used R much more than Python, and Python is kind of new for me. I like how the courses uses lab and jupyter notebooks, but also have descrition of the function. This time I aslo try to combine learning using ChatGPT. E.g. if there is something I am wondering about, I find that some things are more logical an efficent in R (guess that many disagree with me 🙂). Also if there is a function I have used in SQL or Excel, it nice to ask if there is something similar in for Pandas. Another thing that is nice with Google Advanced Data Analytics Professional Certificate, is that it is included in Coursera Plus.

author: @mariaeugeniadiaz3316
text: Thanks for all your videos, I did first certicate with a scholarship , it was good for me because i didn't have any knowledge. Later i did IBM python courses in IBM skillsbuild  and i prefer python :p

author: @coolsweatz
text: I just got approved for financial aid for the original beginner Google Analytics course today, in your opinion for someone who is new to data analytics should I continue with this course or do you think the advanced course is the way forward for everyone?

author: @Hsinking
text: I have completed a long list of ds moocs on different platforms and I found two things: 1,a certificate, no matter what its name is, which uni/company it is from, is a completely different thing than a degree; in most cases it gives width instead of depth, and width alone can not let you have an entry level job ( there is a huge gap between completion of a cert and job ready skills); 2, ds path is already over crowded, a junior or entry level job, as long as it has 'analyst' in its name, will attract a lot more applications than other ones, if all you have is a cert or a dozen of certs then there is very little chance that you can stand out.  I sincerely suggest that unless you have a genuine love for data, otherwise  it is better you choose another path to start your career, it will be a lot easier.
